summary.seg: This manuscript comprises three parts, all probably copied in the 12th century, perhaps in France. The first part, which contains Cicero's Somnium Scipionis (Dream of Scipio) and Macrobius' popular commentary on the text, is probably the oldest part of the manuscript and was made perhaps in the first half of the 12th century. The Somnium Scipionis is an extract from Book 6 of Cicero's De re publica in which Cicero describes a dream vision of the Roman general Scipio Aemilianus. In the dream, Scipio looks down on the city of Carthage from a vantage point in the heavens before turning his attention to describing his celestial surroundings and offering a topography of the earth, sky, planet and stars. Macrobius' Commentarium was an incredibly popular text in medieval western Europe and multiple copies survive - most, like this manuscript, with diagrams that illustrate various portions of Scipio's description of the heavens.

The second part of the volume, ff. 55-138, contains two extremely popular medical works attributed to Mattheus Platearius: his Commentary on the Antidotarium Nicholai known as the 'Liber iste' and his De simplicibus medicinae also known as the 'Circa instans'. The 'Liber iste' is a collection of glosses (detailed explanations) on a popular medical text known as the Antidotarium Nicholai. The 'Circa instans' follows the pattern of typical medieval European herbals, with a sequence of medicinal plants arranged alphabetically and described according to their taxonomy and their uses in various preparations to treat specified medical problems. Both the 'Liber iste' and 'Circa instans' are thought to originate from the milieu of the medical school at Salerno in the second half of the twelfth century and so this part of the manuscript contains early copies of the most up-to-date and respected medical information available in western Europe at the time.

The final part of the volume, ff. 139-140, is a fragment; the two leaves may have once been used as binding waste as the majority of f. 140 has been torn away, and what remains has a visible coating of an adhesive on the verso. Nevertheless, ff. 139-140 preserve several short medical recipe instructions and treatments, so it is possible that the fragment has circulated with at the very least the preceding part of the volume for a long time on account of the similarity of their content, with the two leaves perhaps serving as prepatory research notes, or a place to collect later addenda.

It is not clear when all three parts of the volume came together. The two main parts were listed as one volume in Edward Bernard's 1697 list of the contents of John Moore's collection of manuscripts, but the presence of annotations in late-16th and early-17th century hands in both parts suggest that they may have been bound together for a longer period.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Foliated in the upper outer corner of each recto in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals, mostly by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
foliation.note: Folio numbers ff. 4-5 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). Leaves assigned a folio designation by the Curious Cures project are marked with [square brackets].

collation.p: This manuscript is composite and is comprised of three parts: the first two parts are substantial, with 52 and 84 leaves extant respectively, and the final part is comprised of two leaves. Leaves are missing from the volume in two places, and in both cases the text is interrupted around the missing leaves: Quire 1 is missing its 4th and 5th leaves, and Quire 18 is missing its 1st and 2nd leaves. The final leaf in volume (f. 140) is damaged with over half of the original leaf torn away.

The manuscript is arranged as follows:
Quire 18-2 (ff. 1-8: 4th and 5th leaf missing, with folio numbers 4-5 assigned to missing leaves as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library)
Quires 2-68 (ff. 9-48)
Quire 76 (ff. 49-54) |
Quires 8-118 (ff. 55-86)
Quire 126 (ff. 87-92)
Quire 1310 (ff. 93-102)
Quires 14-178 (ff. 103-134)
Quire 186-2 (ff. 135-138: 1st and 2nd leaf missing, but missing leaves not assigned folio numbers) |
Quire 19two (ff. 139-140)

signatures.p: Quires numbered 1-19 in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals. The lower outer corner of the first recto in the second half of each quire marked with a small '+' in pencil. Added in the 20th century.

additions.note: Occasional glosses and titles to texts and sub-sections in a humanist cursiva (italic) hand of the ?16th century throughout the volume.

List of selected texts from the entire volume in a 17th century hand on f. i verso as follows: 'In hoc volumine continentur:
1. Somnium scipionis
2. Platearii Antidotarium
3. Liber simplicis medicinae secundum ordinem alphabeti'

binding.p: Rebound in March 1967 by Douglas Cockerell and SonDouglas Cockerell and Son in Grantchester, Cambridgeshire. Quarter bound in Morocco leather with marbled paper sides and parchment-tipped corners over millboard. Marbled paper sides are in tones of cream, ochre, brown, and grey in the typical Cockerell style of a dense comb-marbled pattern in geometric forms. Three raised bands on spine. Head and tail bands sewn in a neutral cream yarn. Spine is mid-brown Morocco leather, with blind-tooled single fillets at the upper and lower perimeters of the compartments and horizontally through the centre of the raised bands (i.e., across the width of the spine). Title label in black Morocco leather applied to spine, with title 'MACROBIUS | PLATEARIUS' tooled in gold. Shelfmark label in black Morocco leather applied at the lower opening of the spine with 'Gg.1.10' tooled in gold. Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins. All quires taken down and remounted between paper guards during the 1967 rebinding and some quires resewn - paper stubs visible between quire boundaries throughout the volume.

The left pastedown contains: a note by H.L. Pink recording the 1967 rebinding; another by Pink of the shelfmark 'Gg.1.10', in pencil; a bookplate commemorating the donation of the 'Royal Library'; and an 'F' in pencil, which refers to the size of the book according to a Cambridge University Library classification scheme. The right pastedown contains a collation statement, written in pencil by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
Leaves ff. [a] and [b] are paper, blank, and are cojoint with the pastedowns.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 822 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the left pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the published description on the manuscript in the third volume of the Cambridge University Library Catalogue of Manuscripts (1858, rpr. 1980) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1948 and 1970 by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L., now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75) (Unpublished description by H.L. Pink of Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.1.10 (M. Tullius Cicero, Somnio Scipionis, with commentary by Macrobius; Matthaeus Platearius, Commentaries on Antidotarium Nicholai and De simplicibus medicinae)).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: L'étude des auteurs classiques latins aux XIe et XIIe siècles
L'étude des auteurs classiques latins III:2

series.title: Documents, études et répertoires (Institut de recherche et d'histoire des textes)

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.1.10, ff. i + 1r-54v

msItem.title: Somnium Scipionis [Latin]
msItem.author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
msItem.explicit: 3v Ille discessit ego somno statim solutus sum
msItem.note: The Somnium Scipionis is an extract from Cicero, De re publica VI 9-29 that circulated independently in medieval western Europe. See K. Ziegler (ed.), Teubner (1969), pp. 126-136 for text.
Text is defective due to loss of ff. 4-5.

msItem.title: Commentary on the Somnium Scipionis [Latin]
msItem.author: Ambrosius Aurelius Theodosius Macrobius
msItem.incipit: 6r da patefecit : Ideo et nullum eius simulacrum
msItem.note: Text is defective due to loss of ff. 4-5 and begins at the end of Comm. I.2.15.

listBibl.bibl: Printed by J. Willis (ed.), Macrobius II, Teubner (1970).

msItem.title: Commentary on Macrobius' Commentary on the Somnium Scipionis
msItem.incipit: 54v Macrobius orinicretes ·i· somniorum interpres comentatus est in scipionis apocalipsi
msItem.explicit: 54v non multorum distans eloquio ab ambrosio mediolanensi ep. qui ut multis placet auctor fuit in scribendo hoc libello
msItem.note: A longer version of this text can be found in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.9.23, f. 74v.

msItem.title: Declaration about the transfer of property between a husband and wife
msItem.incipit: 54v Monas trias hoc opus contineat: In exordio mundane creationis
msItem.explicit: 54v ut potestatem habeas faciendi quicquid tuo libuerit arbitrio

list.item: Quire 18-2 (ff. 1-8: 4th and 5th leaf after f. 3 missing, but folio numbers ff. 4-5 assigned to missing leaves as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library)

layout.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame and lines, in single columns. Written above top line, typically 34-35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Main texts written in protogothic minuscule by at least two scribes, and annotated by at least one contemporary hand.

decoNote.p: Marginal diagrams, typically in dark brown but with occasional use of red on ff. 12r, 25r, 30r, 33r, 33v, 36r, 38v, 41v, 43r, 45r.
Red initial with blue pen-flourishing on f. 1r.
Blue initial with red dot decoration on f. 36v.
Rubric in red and blue in a script inspired by capitalis rustica on f. 1r.

note.p: Note recording the presence of the Somnium scipionis on f. i recto in ink in a hand of perhaps the 17th century..

Additional rubric in an English hand of the second half of the 13th century or the first half of the 14th century in the the upper margin of f. 8v: Hic incipit commentum sine expositio ; Sompnii Scipionis above a section of the main text beginning Ostendebat autem Kartaginem (Macrobius, Comm., I.4.5).

Note on f. 54r in an English hand of the second half of the 13th century or the first half of the 14th century describing the contents of another book: In libello qui intitulatur Regula S. Benedicti et Augustinis sunt ·xvi· folia uersus finem de creacione mundi elementis et aliis quoniam ut ait Tullius in prologo Rethoricorum etc.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.1.10, ff. 55r-138v

msItem.title: Commentary on the Antidotarium Nicholai ('Liber iste')
msItem.author: ?Mattheus Platearius (d. 1161)
msItem.rubric: 55r Incipit summa Mattheus Platearius super antidotarium
msItem.explicit: 92v Aliquod prauum sinthoma generet per duos annos seruetur

msItem.title: De simplicibus medicinae ('Circa instans')
msItem.author: ?Mattheus Platearius (d. 1161)
msItem.incipit: 93r Circa instans negotium in medicinis simplicibus
msItem.note: Marginal annotations in contemporary and later hands throughout.

listBibl.bibl: Printed with the works of Serapion, Venice 1497

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 137v Allium calidum est et siccum in medio .iiii. gradus . Allium aliud domesticum aliud siluestre quod scordio appellatur
msItem.explicit: 138r per paruum in illud uas. ad lumbricos occidendos dentur pillule ex galbano inuncte ex melle.
msItem.note: In the same hand as the previous text and rubricated and initialled in the same way.

msItem.title: Medical recipes in several hands
msItem.incipit: 138r Experimentum Iohannis Alemanni contra fistulam in torace sui in corporis stipite absconditam
msItem.explicit: 138v piperis ana que partes elementare siccus denssiores et solidiores partibus
msItem.note: Text is damaged due to rubbing and trimming of the leaf.

p.secFol: 56r cata in puluere detur uel in pilulis

list.item: Quire 186-2 (ff. 135-138: 1st and 2nd leaf missing, but missing leaves not assigned folio numbers)

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Two columns, typically 39-41 lines to the column, written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in protogothic minuscule of the second half of the 12th century by several scribes.

decoNote.p: Red initials, typically 2-3 lines high at the start of each new section of text, typically 3-4 initials per page.
Rubricated (in red) at the start of each new text and each section of text. Rubrication more frequent ff. 93r-137r.

note.p: Recipe to make hair grow in Latin in a late-12th-century hand in empty space on f. 92v after the final rubric for the Commentary on the Antidotarium Nicholai (Liber iste).
Additional recipes, corrections, and glosses added to margins ff. 55r-138v in several hands.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.1.10, ff. 139-140

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 139r in certa quantitate predicta et bulliant in oleo oliuario uel buturo ad tepidum ignem
msItem.note: Folio 140 is a torn fragment, probably a former pastedown as it has adhesive staining on the verso. The remaining text on the leaf, and particularly on the verso is rubbed and stained and only partial readings are possible.

extent.seg: Fragment: two leaves from a late-12th century or early-13th-century manuscript.

collation.p: Two leaves, with significant damage to the 2nd leaf (f. 140).

condition.p: The majority of f. 140 has been torn away; the remainder of 140v is stained with an adhesive residue, so the leaf was perhaps once used as a pastedown in a former binding. The leaf has undergone conservative restoration; the missing portion of the leaf has been restored with a graft of paper, and holes in the remaining parchment have been filled with conservation silk.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and lines. Double columns, 63 lines to the column, written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in protogothic minuscule between narrow lines; text is particularly small and cramped.

change.persName: Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
